body.p: We will use the Best Actor Oscar winners (1970–2013) to learn how to create a histogram using a statistics package and practice what we've learned about describing the histogram.
Click here to see the entire dataset.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To open R with the dataset preloaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in R.
The data have been loaded into the data frame actor_age . Enter the command actor_age to see the data. The only variable (column title) in the data frame actor_age is Age .
To create a histogram of the actors’ age data we can use the following code:

Notice the default settings in R are to use the variable name, in this case actor_age$Age in the title and x-axis label. In addition, the default y-axis is "Frequency." A good graphic is a well-labeled graphic. We can modify all of these settings with a few additional parameters added into the hist() command.
For example, if you want to add an x-axis label and remove the title of the histogram, use the following code:

p.code: hist(actor_age$Age, xlab="Age of Best Actor Oscar Winners (1970-2013)", main="")

alternative.p: If you want to modify the x-axis and y-axis label and the title use the following code:

p.code: hist(actor_age$Age, xlab="Age of Best Actor Oscar Winners (1970-2013)", ylab="Number of Actors", main="Best Actor Oscar Winners Ages")

alternative.p: Try replacing the x-axis label, y-axis label, and title with your own modified labels.

Another possible modification to the histogram is the number of bins. R uses an algorithm to determine the optimal number of bins based on the data, but in some cases you may want to modify the number of bins yourself. You can add the parameter breaks= into the hist() command, which will tell R to make that many breaks in the data. R will not always do the exact number of breaks if it is not possible, but it will provide a close approximation. For example, let’s try 8 breaks:

p.code: hist(actor_age$Age, breaks=8, xlab="Age of Best Actor Oscar Winners (1970-2013)", main="")

alternative.p: Try replacing the number of "breaks" with 5 or 20. Which histogram gives the right amount of detail—neither too little nor too much?

Note: Using R—If you are looking at a graph in R, you may find that the command window (the one labeled "R Console") is not responsive. That is because the graph window is the "active" window. Click on the command window to make it the active window. In addition, notice that R will always overwrite your current graphic with a new graphic. Enter the code x11() and press prior to each new graphic command and R will create a new window for that graphic.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To open the dataset, click here to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel. When Excel opens you may have to enable editing.
Now create a histogram of the actors' age data:

li.p: First we need to define the bins that Excel will use to create the histogram. In this case, our minimum data point is 29, and our max is 76. We'll use a bin width of 5, and make bins from 25 to 79:
In an empty cell type Bin and in the cell to the right type Frequency.

In the cell under Bin put the different bins based on the bin width of 5. Here the first bin would be 25-29. Continue adding bins by typing 30-34, 35-39, 40-44, etc. When finished you should have 11 bins.

Next sort the data by first highlighting the entire dataset and then selecting sort smallest to largest from the pop-up menu that appears by pressing the Sort and Filter button from the Editing group on the Home tab.
With the data sorted, you can count the number that would fit into each bin and put those counts in the column under Frequency.

Now highlight the Bin and Frequency columns. Then navigate to the Insert tab, find the Chart group and click on the insert column chart button (the picture of an upright bar graph). From there select clustered column under 2-D column .
Histograms shouldn't have spaces between the bars, so right-click on one of the bars and choose Format Data Series . Then set the gap width to 0% (No Gap).
Before closing the Format Data Series window, click on Border under Fill and Line on the left, choose Solid line , and set the color to black.

Xscl=5—this is the distance between the tick marks on the X scale, and determines how wide each class is.
